title: Status Codes
section:
Modify the title of the chart, and make use of various HTML tags , ,
, , ,
text:
Modify the title of the chart, and make use of various HTML tags <a>, <b>, <br>, <i>, <sub>, <sup>

website = 'MyWebsite.com'
title = f'Error Codes distribution <b>400</b> and <b>500</b><br>clickable: <i><a href="https://mywebsite.com">{website}</i> ‚Äì April 3, 2023'

status_codes(
    codes.query('status >= 400')['status'],
    title=title,
    height=700,
    width=1300,
    theme='ggplot2')

title: Flag Emojis with adviz
section: Adding country flags makes them easily recognizable
text:
Adding country flags makes them easily recognizable


Code
import plotly.express as px
fig = px.bar(
    population,
    x='country',
    y='population',
    height=500, 
    text=[adviz.flag(cc) for cc in population['code']],
    template='plotly_dark'
)
fig.data[0].textfont.size = 35
fig.data[0].marker.color = 'steelblue'
fig

title: Flag Emojis with adviz
text:
Horizontal chart


Code
fig = px.bar(
    population.sort_values('population'),
    y='country',
    x='population',
    orientation='h',
    height=500, 
    opacity=0.8,
    text=[adviz.flag(cc) for cc in population.sort_values('population')['code']],
    template='plotly_dark'
)
fig.data[0].textfont.size = 35
fig.data[0].marker.color = 'teal'
fig

title: adviz
text:
advertools is a package for the search (SEO/SEM) and digital marketing practitioner. It aims to help with various productivity and analysis tools.
Part of the analysis process is producing specialized charts that tend to come up all the time. So, adviz aims to be a collection of charts that can help advertools users. Many of the charts can be used for many other workflows, and are not marketing-specific. Feel free to use, share, and suggest features for any of them.
Get started quickly and see examples below:

advertools is a package for the search (SEO/SEM) and digital marketing practitioner. It aims to help with various productivity and analysis tools.
Part of the analysis process is producing specialized charts that tend to come up all the time. So, adviz aims to be a collection of charts that can help advertools users. Many of the charts can be used for many other workflows, and are not marketing-specific. Feel free to use, share, and suggest features for any of them.

title: Counting values
text:
Usage
Generate a random list of 10,000 colors


Code
import random
import numpy as np
import matplotlib as mpl
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

colors = list(mpl.colors.cnames.keys())
colors = random.choices(colors, weights=[0.9, 0.04, 0.05, 0.09]*37, k=10_000)
colors += [np.nan for i in range(240)]
colors[:20]

title: Styling Tables
section: Styling multiple columns with multiple chart types
text:
Styling multiple columns with multiple chart types
First set the categorical order so we can sort medals by rank: bronze < silver < gold.

medals = px.data.medals_long()[['medal', 'nation', 'count']]
medals['medal'] = (medals['medal']
                   .astype('category')
                   .cat.reorder_categories(['bronze', 'silver', 'gold']))
medals = medals.sort_values(['medal', 'count'], ascending=False)

Since each column contains a different type of data, we want to set the types of chart we want ot use to visualize them:

medal: category
nation: category
count: bar

Note that when you have two categorical columns, different color scales are used to avoid confusion.

style_table(
    medals,
    column_types=['category', 'category', 'bar'],
    title='Olympic Medals',
    theme='none',
    precision=0,
    width=800,
    height=500)

                                                


You can also use ‚Äúheatmap‚Äù for numeric columns, and it depends on how you want to display it.

style_table(
    medals,
    column_types=['category', 'category', 'heatmap'],
    title='Olympic Medals',
    theme='none',
    precision=0,
    width=800,
    height=400)

Using column_widths we can set the relative widths of each chart as appropriate. This can be set as any fraction between [0, 1]. The columns that contain a lot of data (like text for example) can be given a larger share of the chart, and you can interactively modify the widths using a list.

)

title: Styling Tables
section: Producing more detailed and readable tables
text:
Producing more detailed and readable tables
With large tables and many values, it‚Äôs good to filter and display the subset that you want, as we do here with the gapminder dataset. We first sort values by year and gdpPercap, and then get the top five countries for each year. Then we rename the columns to give them a nicer look.

top5_gdp_percap = (px.data
                   .gapminder()
                   .sort_values(['year', 'gdpPercap'],
                                ascending=[True, False])
                   .groupby('year').head().iloc[:, :-2]
                   [['country', 'continent', 'year', 'gdpPercap', 'lifeExp', 'pop']]
                   .rename(columns={
                       'gdpPercap': 'GDP per capita',
                       'lifeExp': 'Life expectancy',
                       'pop': 'population'}))

title: Racing Bar Chart
section: Explore the top queries by month (impressions)
text:
Explore the top queries by month (impressions)
Queries can be long and take a lot of space, so we can set the left margin of the Figure object to a larger number to fit them.

fig = racing_chart(
    queries[['query', 'impressions', 'date']],
    title='Google Search Console <b>mywebsite.com</b><br>impressions per month - top 15',
    n=15,
    theme='seaborn',
    height=800)
fig.layout.margin.l = 250
fig

title: Racing Bar Chart
text:
Filtering entities
Taking a look at the top queries is definitely interesting, but many times you may have tens or hundreds of thousands of queries, and you want to go deeper.
One way is to filter those based on some criterion.
For example, let‚Äôs see which are the top queries that contain ‚Äúlog‚Äù and see how we are doing on log file analysis queries:

fig = racing_chart(
    queries[queries['query'].str.contains('log')][['query', 'impressions', 'date']],
    title='Google Search Console <b>mywebsite.com</b> - queries containing "log"<br>impressions per month - top 15',
    n=15,
    theme='seaborn',
    height=800)
fig.layout.margin.l = 250
fig

title: Counting Values
text:
Counting continuous data
We can easily make continuous data discrete by binning them. One easy way to do that is the pandas.cut function.
For example, if we want to count countries‚Äô populations, we can first bin them under 50M intervals, and run value_counts_plus.

gm = px.data.gapminder().query('year == 2007')
gm['pop_interval'] = pd.cut(gm['pop'], range(0, 1_500_000_000, 50_000_000))

Watch a discussion about analyzing SERPs:


This SERP dataset was created by running the adv.serp_goog function as follows:

Get the top 36 crypto currencies‚Äô names
Generate two variations for each coin: ‚Äúwhat is <coin>‚Äù and ‚Äú<coin> price‚Äù
Run the serp_goog function for all coins, query variations and in two countries, US, and UK



36 coins x 2 variations x 2 countries = 144 requests (1,440 SERP results)
As you can see, there are numerous columns that are returned by the API, although many of them are empty. The default ones will always be full though, and they are placed in the beginning of the DataFrame.

We can easily create our hetmap with one command:

serp_heatmap(serp)

title: SERP Heatmap
section: Modify some of the default options
text:
Modify some of the default options

serp_heatmap(
    serp,
    num_domains=15,
    title='SERP Heatmap - crypto currencies<br><b>"what is <coin>" and "<coin> price"',
    theme='ggplot2')

title: SERP Heatmap
text:
SERP Heatmap chart details

Avg. Pos.: The average position of the domain shown on this column
Coverage: The number of appearances of the domain on the SERP, divided by the total queries. A ratio above 100% can exist, where some domains appear more than once in the same SERP.
Total appearances: the number of times the domain appeared in the SERP (from this dataset).
Numbers in circles: Show the number of times each domain appeared in its respective position.

title: SERP Heatmap
text:
Data from other sources
This chart doest not need the data from Google custom search API exclusively. There are other similar data sources like YouTube, SERP API, and SearchAPI for example. The only requirement is that you have a DataFrame with ‚Äúrank‚Äù, ‚ÄúsearchTerms‚Äù, and ‚ÄúdisplayLink‚Äù. These columns might be named differently, in which case you only need to rename those columns. You might have ‚ÄúsearchTerms‚Äù named as ‚Äúkeyword‚Äù or ‚Äúquery‚Äù for example, or ‚ÄúdisplayLink‚Äù named ‚Äúdomain‚Äù. This should be straightforward.
